review_title: Easy Job, But Don't Get Too Comfortable
pros:
Easy once you get the hang of it.

Great work environment, although this particular office is very small.
cons:
Seniority can be an issue. This department caters to its long-time employees who account for the majority of the first shift. You will be scheduled around them!

If you are written up, you can not transfer to another department.

Also, little to no room for advancement in this position.

If you looking to get your foot in the door, then get in and get out before you get too comfortable.

review_title: If I could leave Cooper zero stars I would
pros:
-Well Renowned hospital
-STRONG UNION
cons: New to practice RNs BEWARE. Several new grads, including myself were pressured into signing 2 year "contract" that was presented well about an entire month of being on board without a warning or explanation. No such contract was mentioned during interview, hospital orientation, or "boot camp." Leadership stated that this is a "retention tactic." This is extremely unethical and embarrassing. Cooper underestimates that new grads have a voice and will be aware of the resources available to them.

Disrespectful employees to patients...and then my actual job...that had to be done while I did everything else was all the messages, calls to the nurse in that was me, every refill, tjtu phone fax and the appointments in for the day...Youre at a desck going crazy or running around like a nut grooming patients and doing patient care and procedures visits and injections

pros: Lots of PTO, vacation time, pay is OK- 34.00/hr for new grads, 5 (x2) call outs a year, double time for mandatory holidays, 4 weekend shifts in a 6 week schedule, decent christmas bonus ~400$. I met alot of great, but burnout people. The only way i would go back to this hospital is to work in the OR, CCU, or Pavillion 7 orthopedics.
cons: VERY expensive health care compared to other hospitals (me + husband is 211$ dollars biweekly), understaffed (typical of any hospital), very sick patients with high ratio 6:1. We get transfers for escalation of care from all over the state.  Way too many huddles from clinical directors- we want to go home were tired and not listening anyway. They "write you up" for anything and everything. Parking is a nightmare if you work dayshift. They make you shuttle from the waterfront- its an additional 7 min to your commute one way (if you happen to get a seat right away- usually waiting in the cold for a shuttle to pick you up).  If i sound bitter, its because i am.

pros:
1.  Interesting work.
2.  Most coworkers  were friendly and helpful.
3.  Pay was good for the Philadelphia area.
cons:
1. Management is poor.  I observed three types: 

a.  The outright rude who would curse during meetings, demean employees.
b.  The busybody, micro-manager that make those around them distraught and the workplace hectic.
c.  The aloof who were almost non-existent in their leadership, until something went wrong.  Then, they'd become a mixture of the first two types.

2. Some coworkers are nasty.  This can happen anywhere, but it goes beyond the typical backstabbing, gossiping, etc., because some of these people have the ears of leadership and use it to adversely affect others.

3. Lack of honesty from leadership.  There's a sense of falseness at times when information is disseminated or when some action is promised to be taken.  Sometimes it's an omission, sometimes it's a commission.  Either way, no one likes being lied to, especially from those in a position of leadership.

4. Benefits were not great.  They were expensive and appeared limited to the hospital system itself.

pros:
Opportunity to work with vulnerable population with addictions and complex medical conditions.

Coworkers makes coming to work worth it. 

No parking(con) 
Low pay(con)
cons:
Not enough space to discuss the cons.
I have been working in this department for over 2 years and the if the racism, discrimination, gossip, turnover rate, overworked/underpaid staff isn’t enough to get a lawsuit, i don’t know what else is.

This department is a disgrace. Management is so busy gossiping with employees that they can’t see how bad the department is failing. Patients complain about the treatment here. Everytime i turn around somebody is quitting. From bullying, to underpayment 

Who did management have to sleep with to get into their positions? They are so disconnected from the floor, the community and the patients that they mind as well be managing the office from Mars. I have witness employees retaliated against because they have filed complaints with HR! 

When Jeff was around, things were smoother and more diverse. Once he left, everything became white washed, which is kind of ironic because the department is geared to an urban population.

job_title: Licensed Practical Nurse in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: Great healthcare benefits and paid time off
cons: Company is focused more on numbers, ratings and money the company can make, rather  than the employees.  Work atmosphere can be like high school at times with catty like behavior, cliques and those that smile in your face but talk about you behind your back.  Managers tend to have their favorites and look out for them while others are left working their butts off to do the job the office golden children won't do

review_title: It's a business, not about the care of the patients.  All about $$$
pros: I do apologize I can't think of any!
cons: Employees pay for parking, making sure they have a full schedule but many times no room for the patients, managers don't hear both sides of a situation, don't work with your schedule for improvement in the department, don't have enough parking shuttle from Camden waterfront not safe for employees, managers will stab you in the back, if you have a concern they will wait until something happens before you can get results.  Don't work here!

pros: Since they are unionized you can expect excellent salary and benefits.
cons:
I felt as if I was becoming a trained robot.  Too many rules and regulations, wasn't conducive to brain storming and forming new ways to achieve excellence with in my department.   MD charting would reflect same information every single day even though certain orders had been d/c'd, it appeared as if they were still active.
Also very quick to terminate your position if you are out on medical leave too long.

pros: Diverse learning experience, fast paced, many opportunities for educational enhancement
cons: After completing my pediatric and maternity clinicals here I fell in love. I was extremely excited to accept my first nursing position on the med surg floor. I had no idea it would be a nightmare. Management was very unprofessional. As a new nurse I was paired with a nurse preceptor that had a reputation for making new nurses quit. She never had anything to say when I asked her what I needed to improve on, but called a meeting with the nurse supervisor to ambush me with things I wasn't doing right. After multiple request to switch preceptors I was finally granted an older male nurse who had no complaints about my performance. Management still bullied me after the new preceptor refused to say anything negative. They then said, "You look miserable here and its all about preception." I wouldn't recommend working here.

job_title: Certified Medical Assistant in Voorhees, NJ
pros: Kinda health benefits. If u stay with cooper doctors, tuition reimbursement
cons: Administration is a revolving door. Manager is out is place just to have somebody there, weather educated or any experience in the position. Very understaffed , Under-payed and over worked. Never recognized for the work you do well.  Dr’s are completely unhappy with upper management which caused a lot of great physicians to leave. HR does not help staff what so ever. Nor are they rarely available to speak with. Favoritisms is huge, and fear of racial discrimination from management caused unfair treatment across the board to all employees. Everyone is NOT treated the same. All in all it’s a very un happy un-motivating establishment time work for. Always watch ur back.

pros: I worked with some great folks at Cooper.  They made the job bearable.
cons: Where shall I begin? Over dependence on consultants.  Management only responds to their favorites. Fairness and decency to the line employees (those that actually do the work in the hospital) is almost nonexistent.  No equity in which departments get money/employees to fulfill their mission.  Management decisions are perceived as capricious and probably are just that.  The policy that everyone, regardless of their position in the hospital, is subject to the "Golden Rule" is a cruel farce.  The people at the" bottom of the pyramid" are still routinely demeaned and debased by the higher ups and the medical staff.

job_title: Critical Care Technician in Camden, NJ
pros: Benefits is about all i can think of
cons: Coworkers are caddy and act like bullies,   long hours with few breaks

review_title: You can be fired for no reason.
pros: -decent benefits and ease of parking
cons: This lady from human resources has an unstable grasp of her emotions and will take out her frustrations on unsuspecting coworkers. Don't ever take a call from her on your day off. My wife is much happier working somewhere else. Submit your work application at another hospital. You will be glad you did. They don't value their staff and will throw you to the curb for no reason. Job security is pretty much non existent. They are fickle and unreasonable.

pros: There are dedicated, committed physicians and staff members working to make a difference everyday for patients.  It is a fast-paced environment.  Salaries for mid level and above are fair market value.  Compensation for service level employees is low.
cons: Top management changes have adversely affected the relationship between management and staff.  There is a bullying attitude from executives.  Patient satisfaction will not improve until employee satisfaction is improved.

review_title: This company has given me the opportunity to learn and grow into my career. They  are most definitively a great teaching
pros: Great pay , great benefits , on site parking , .Great Teaching hospital .  Great location if you live in Philadelphia or New Jersey.
cons: You pay for parking ,high rates for medical insurance especially for families.   Working understaffed even though numbers are increasing . You work hard for your money .

job_title: Critical Care Technician in Camden, NJ
pros:
Most people working at Cooper are pleasant and easy to work with. My particular department works very well together and most try to help out when they can. 
Benefits are ok. Better if you use Cooper doctors. 
Continuing education is encouraged and you are compensated for money spent. 
Christmas bonus.
cons:
Never enough Techs staffed on busy unit. Management only seems to care about nurses concerns and needs. During Tech Week, we were handed a $5 voucher for the cafeteria. 
No hazard pay being exposed to COVID-19. 
No cost of living raise.

pros: Salary was very good for experience, the physicians and doctors are world class. Few diamond in the rough employees among a sea of clueless people. Great healthcare benefits
cons: Upper management is useless and clueless to running a successful system. No checks and balances in play, high employment turnover rate, high billing mistakes due to hiring under skilled lower hourly employees, lower salary employees not vetted properly. Threatning to make people come in to work during snowstorms or get fired

pros: Flexible hour, good pay, helpful, kind coworkers, not too stressful, management is nice and willing to help you if you ask, seem to care about the work environment.
cons: Frequently messes up scheduled hours, unknown assignment until you get there, frequent 1:1's, will fire you if your online learning isn't done on time  (coworkers)

job_title: Emergency Department Technician in Camden, NJ
pros: Great staff, all of my coworkers are amazing. I learn a lot from the staff and am constantly encouraged to keep up my skills and education.
cons: As with any hospital, there is often not enough staff for the patient load. There has been an increase in responsiveness from upper management, but often it seems like there is no advocate and no one to listen.

pros: Great benefits and they do pay for some certs/continuing education.
cons:
If you're not involved in patient care you're a second class department.
Managers played favorites, even with other mangers.
Performance reports used to reward cronies and punish those who don't brown nose and boot lick.
Clear ageism and lookism issues to go with rampant cronyism,e.g. the young and beautiful friends of the manager got treated the best regardless of performance.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Gloucester City, NJ
pros:
Many nurses that I worked with are very compassionate, smart , the kind of nurse you would want to take care of your mom and dad. 
Flexible work areas
Employees solutions
cons:
The Union stinks! It was developed to help staff but it really doesn't it's a racket!
Upper executives get to know your staff ... think rounds with staff or just walk on the floors and say "Hello ".

pros: Helped me learn the ropes - was my first lab job after getting certified as a CMA. Great on the job training.
cons: Understaffed sometimes in the lab. Always had too much to do and everything was STAT with doctors phoning us every five minutes for results that take at least fifteen or twenty minutes to run.

pros: Friendly hospital staff, excellent introductory role to patient care, able to meet staff throughout the hospital, flexible with student schedules
cons: Poorly organized department, few opportunities for career advancement, department staff and managers have limited training and knowledge of patient care,  understaffed, use PRN employees for Part Time hours, HR department is very unresponsive

pros: Benefits are good if you use within the cooper network, the tuition reimbursement is a plus. There are times where scheduling is slightly more flexible with the individual.
cons: Terrible management and pay isn't comparable to the rest of the industries pay grade. Employees are under appreciated and the departments across the board are never adequately staffed and new employees are never properly trained.

pros: Great co-workers; the staff are very nice. Benefits package is amazing. Orientation for employees was great
cons: need more accountability to new employees, there is not enough on the job training in my opinion, I have had to fend for myself, that is not good.

review_title: It's a busy environment. Chance to learn new areas in the clerical field.
job_title: Patient Service Representative II in Camden, NJ
pros: Cooper pays for a portion of continuing education.  Which makes it easy for school and work to a realistic goal for an adult.
cons: One title but a dozen responsibilities. It becomes overwhelming. You tend to not do your job whole heartedly when you feel you are being taken advantage of.

pros: It's the best place to work. Great benefits and all that . Work with you on school and 2nd jobs
cons: 1 write up and you can't get promoted or move to another department for a WHOLE YEAR. which is bad. Pay raise is kinda slow. You only get a raise a while

pros:
Salary is decent compared to last job
Learned a lot
Co workers are nice and helpful 
That’s it really not sure what else to say here
cons:
Management Very unorganized 
Insurance is extremely high 
Turn over is ridiculously high 
Expectations are not realistic at all
It sometimes feels like they are setting you up for failure

review_title: Company has decent pay however compared to high level of stress you have to deal with its not worth it
job_title: Patient Services Supervisor in Camden, NJ
pros: Nice benefits package with pleanty of PTO days .
cons: Some departments a cliquey.  Upper management usually has their few picks over everyone else.  Alot of talent goes hidden because of that.

pros: The healthcare benefits are really good, as long as you use Cooper physicians or go to Cooper hospital
cons: Management is not very good and the pay is not very competitive. Also, there's no benefit to being certified and no way to move up in the company

review_title: Great co-workers and supportive unit managers in the PACU
job_title: Registered Nurse in Gloucester City, NJ
pros: Great experience! Managers support us! Always busy! Love my coworkers! Doctors trust their nurses who are at the bedside which makes for a great relationship with them at work!
cons: A lot of overflow with ICU patients that sometimes makes it hard to manage the surgical flow of patients! Definitely need more staff throughout the whole hospital!

pros: Excellent place to work.  Love the people and my job.  Grateful for all the talented staff I work with .  One of a kind.
cons: I have nothing negative to say.  The team at Cooper is extraordinary, kind, compassionate, friendly supportive, service oriented and special.

pros: vacation time and the day I resigned.
cons: if you are an hourly employee you will work your full 40 hours while nonsalaried employees come and go as they please.  I did not think this was fair because I punched in and out.  Then I found another job and gladly resigned.  Job descriptions are underrated and then you find out differently once you begin learning your responsibilities.  My position was recently reclassified in order for someone to stay since they have not found someone to stay for 2 years so far.  Each person that had this position resigned.  Isn't that interesting...  I did not even get an exit interview since they knew I may tell HR everything that was going on in that department.  Instead, I write it here and I left to never look back.  It is not the best place to work at all.  The hire ups almost force you to give a good review or else your job is in jeopardy.  They say anonymous yet a number is assigned.  So everyone feels obligated to lie on review for example The Best Place to Work Review but it is not.  Cooper is the WORST place I have every worked and I am very happy I am out of there.

review_title: I enjoy who I work with but the pay is terrible and no raises for 3 years
job_title: Patient Service Representative II in Voorhees, NJ
pros: Only good thing is the benefits and time off.
cons: No raises. Management is  not in touch with what we really do they just want MORE.

job_title: Patient Service Representative II in Salem, OR
pros: Good benefits. Salary ok. Caring deeply For patients. Room for growth. Big organization. Outside offices  as well as the hospital to seek employment in other location.
cons: As with many jobs there's pros and cons. In my personal experience as of now the only thing I see are the annual raises. Very low percentage.  However many places are the same though.

pros:
Freedom with making your own hours

if you put in time you get the pay

after your third 12hr shift you hit overtime pay .. ==time 1/2
cons:
Long hours


boring

just sitting there in the room 

staffing is unorganized and all they do is gossip 

cooper has its clicks 

management doesn't care about lower level employees

feels like high school -- unproductive environment

job_title: Senior Applications Analyst in Camden, NJ
pros: Job was challenging and very interesting. Enjoyed the job itself.  Salary and benefits were great as well.
cons: Very cliquey. If you are not liked by someone in the clique your job becomes twice as hard.  Very stressful environment

pros: It keeps me busy and I love the overtime
cons: Having to go behind people who aren't performing there jobs people who has been there over ten years

job_title: Charge Entry Specialist in Camden, NJ
pros: its an good place to work for and room for advancement
cons: when calling out of work it is an unscheduled day and you have doctor or hospital documentation I think it should not be used against you when wanting to move and prosper to another department

pros: Good health insurance and benefits!
cons: The some of the people are nasty and like to take short cuts on their work and it puts the whole hospital at risk!

review_title: Cooper has potential to be a great employer.
pros: competitive salaries, reasonable & convienient parking fees, no city wage taxes
cons: No management training / upward mobility programs

job_title: Clinical Practice Assistant II in Camden, NJ
pros: Cooper has great patient care. They also have great opportunity to work with a variety of specialty doctors. Flexible hours. Tuition reimbursements. Credential renewal reimbursement.
cons: Underpaid. No vertime allowed. Overworked. Too many chiefs not enough indians. Have to use our personal time off to cover vacations, holidays, sick days... etc...

pros:
Organization at large does a lot of good for the camden community
Pharmacy department is like your average dysfunctional family

Little to no career mobility

cons: Lack of communication between the techs and RNS, lack of teamwork, lazy nurses who never get call bells or ask the techs to do everything, ever single unit I’ve been on is short staffed, difficult patient population (sometimes)

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Cherry Hill, NJ
pros: The only pro was me leaving

pros: If you're looking to further your education then  Cooper is the place for you.  As a Surgical Scheduler who wants to become a nurse I took full advantage of their Tuition Advancement benefits!
